'''442oons''' is an English [[YouTube]] [[animation]] [[parody]] channel set up in 2013. The channel focuses on animated [[association football]] parodies, such as [[Premier League]], [[La Liga]] and [[Bundesliga]] matches. He now works with Bundesliga to make weekly videos on the channel.
==Career== The channels' creator, Dean Stobbart, originally a teacher from [[Norton, County Durham]], had in the past been a part-time voice actor, along with being a professional actor starring in productions on the West End including Our House (musical) and also did some animation for his lessons. He said he saw a gap in the market that "no one had really done football cartoons before", so he used CrazyTalk (Animator software) to make his first animated video, a parody of [[Luis Su√°rez]] and former [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] manager [[Ars√®ne Wenger]] in a cartoon parody of a scene from [[The Silence of the Lambs (film)|''The Silence of the Lambs'']]. The video currently has 2.312 million views and was followed up with another Su√°rez-themed video which has received more than fourteen million views.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eLhUgkO7Zxg|title=üòÅLUIS SUAREZ BITEüòÅ by 442oons (Suarez Evra Ivanovic football cartoon) Seven Sins of Suarez|last=|first=|date=2018-08-24|website=YouTube|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-21}}</ref> Since then he has worked with organisations such as ''[[TalkSport]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://talksport.com/football/best-football-april-fool-them-all-442oons-sends-bayern-munich-stars-150401141853|title=The best football April Fool of them all? 442oons sends up Bayern Munich stars|first=|last=talkSPORT|date=1 April 2015|publisher=|accessdate=14 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://talksport.com/football/mourinho-v-sterling-video-footage-you-didnt-see-liverpool-v-chelsea-150121133222|title=Mourinho v Sterling: The video footage YOU DIDN'T SEE from Liverpool v Chelsea!|first=Craig|last=Bloomfield|date=21 January 2015|publisher=|accessdate=14 December 2017}}</ref> and ''[[SkySports]]'' on animations. His videos have also been featured on ''[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.google.co.uk/search?q=442oons&ie=utf-8&oe=utf-8&client=firefox-b&gfe_rd=cr&ei=gUGxWLbaF67S8Ae0m4go#tbm=nws&q=442oons+metro&*|title=442oons - Google Search|website=www.google.co.uk|accessdate=14 December 2017}}</ref> and the Spanish ''[[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marca.com/en/football/barcelona/2016/04/14/570f82c6e5fdeaaf688b45b8.html|title=The 4 conspiracy theories surrounding Gabi's 'penalty' - MARCA English|publisher=|accessdate=14 December 2017}}</ref> He said in an interview with ''[[Tubefilter]]'' that his next goal is to have two million subscribers (which he reached in July 2018).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tubefilter.com/2017/02/16/youtube-millionaires-442oons/|title=YouTube Millionaires: 442oons Animates The "Ridiculous World Of Football"|date=16 February 2017|publisher=|accessdate=14 December 2017}}</ref> Although Stobbart had originally created his videos by himself, he has now hired three animators, Sam Dunscombe, Mike Myler and James Williams.
In July 2017, he created a new YouTube channel parodying the celebrity world called Celebri2oons.<ref>{{Channel|https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC4m9rhlOV1VCFbqZJXpVcFw|Celebri2oons}} on YouTube</ref>
Since 30th May 2018. Online Soccer Manager (OSM) became an official 442oons mobile game. League with 442oons teams and players was added in the Special Leagues section and it's named 442oons Suuuuuper League. There are total 14 teams in this league. Teams in this league are Bayern Munchausen, Money Utd, DIY Army, Old Lady, Man Sheikhy, PSlotsofG, Ronal Madrid, Chelski, Atlediego Madrid, Barcelionela, Leavethepool, DVD, Arsene FC and Managers FC. There are also 442oons characters which don't belong to any team and they are free agents.

{{use dmy dates|date=November 2016}} {{use Indian English|date=November 2016}} {{Infobox royalty | title = Rajakesari | image = aditya territories.png | alt = | caption = ''Chola Territories c. 905 CE'' | reign = 870‚Äì907 CE | predecessor = [[Vijayalaya Chola]] | successor = [[Parantaka I]] | spouse = Tribhuvanamadeviyar
Ilangon Pichchi | spouse-type = Queen | issue = Parantaka | father = Vijayalaya Chola | birth_date = Unknown | birth_place = | death_date = 907 CE }} {{chola history}} '''Aditya I''' (c. 870 ‚Äì c. 907 CE), the son of [[Vijayalaya Chola|Vijayalaya]], was the [[Chola]] king who extended the Chola dominions by the conquest of the [[Pallavas]] and occupied the [[Western Ganga Kingdom]].{{Cite book |last=Sen |first=Sailendra |title=A Textbook of Medieval Indian History |publisher=Primus Books |year=2013 |isbn=978-9-38060-734-4 |pages=46‚Äì49}} == Pallava Civil War == During the [[Vijayalaya Chola#Pandyan invasion|invasion of the Chola country]], the Pandya king [[Varagunavarman II]] became an ally of Nripatunga, the eldest son of the Pallava King [[Nandivarman III]]. When Nandivarman died in 869 CE differences arose between Nripatunga and his stepbrother [[Aparajitavarman|Aparajita]], probably owing to the latter‚Äôs ambition to rule the kingdom on his own right. Both sides looked for allies. Nripatunga continued to have Varaguna Pandya by his side while Aparajita allied with the [[Western Ganga Dynasty|Ganga]] king Prithvipathi I and with Aditya Chola I. According to some descriptions Aparajitha was found to be noted as son of Nirpatunga Varma, and his mother was noted as Prithivi Manikam daughter of Ganga king. So the Contention that Prithivapathi 1 gone against Nirpatunga was totally un accepatable The rival armies met at Thirupurambiyam near [[Kumbakonam]] c. 885 CE. The armies of Pandyas and Nripatunga Pallava were routed by Aparajita Pallava and Aditya I Chola. But Some Inscriptions purely clarified Nirpatunga Was not alive during the war.{{cn|date=February 2018}} So it is the war between Pallvas and Pandiyas to establish Legal Supremacy == Ascendancy == {{anchor|}} {{anchor|Ascendancy|Aditya I's Ascendancy}} Although the victor of the Thirupurambiyam battle was Aparajita, the real gains went to Aditya I Chola. This battle ensured the end of Pandya power in the south. Pandya Varagunavarman renounced his throne and followed an [[ascetic]] life. The grateful Aparajita not only allowed Aditya I Chola to keep the territories won by Vijayalaya Chola, but also to add new territories from the defeated Pandyas. == Invasion of the Pallava Country == {{anchor|Invasion of the Pallava Country|Aditya I‚Äôs invasion of the Pallava Country}} During 903 CE, the 32nd year of his reign, Aditya I Chola, not satisfied with his subordinate position, planned and carried out an attack on his erstwhile overlord, the Pallava king Aparajita. In the battle that ensued, Aditya pounced upon Aparajita when he was mounted on an elephant and killed him. That spelt the end of the Pallava rule in [[History of Chennai#Ancient area in South India|Tondaimandalam]] (north [[Tamil Nadu]]) and the whole of the Pallava kingdom became Chola territory. This marked the effective end of the once great Pallava empire in the history of South India. {{citation needed|date=August 2016}} The conquest of the Tondaimandalam earned for Aditya I the epithet "''Tondainadu pavina Rajakesarivarman''" (‡Æ§‡Øä‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡Øà‡Æ®‡Ææ‡Æü‡ØÅ ‡Æ™‡Ææ‡Æµ‡Æø‡Æ© ‡Æá‡Æ∞‡Ææ‡Æö‡Æï‡Øá‡Æö‡Æ∞‡Æø‡Æµ‡Æ∞‡Øç‡ÆÆ‡Æ©‡Øç) - "Rajakesarivarman who overran Tondainadu". == The Conquest of Kongu == Aditya I next conquered the Kongu country in the south west of Tamil Nadu, perhaps from the Pandya king Viranarayana. == Relations with the Cheras == Friendly relations appear to have existed between the [[Chera dynasty|Chera]]s and the Cholas during the reign of Aditya  I. The Chera contemporary Sthanu Ravi is stated in inscriptions to have received royal honours from Aditya. AdityaI ‚Äôs son, [[Parantaka I]], married a daughter of Sthanu Ravi. == Aditya‚Äôs contributions to Temples== Aditya I is known to have built a number of temples 108 for [[Shiva]] along the banks of the [[Kaveri]]. The Kanyakumari inscription gives us the information that Aditya I was also known by the surname '''Kodandarama'''. There is a temple near the town of Tondaimanarrur called ''Kodandarameshvaraa'', also mentioned in its inscriptions by the name ''Adityesvara''. This seems to have been built by Aditya I. He also revised Annamalaiyar sanctum in Thiruvaannamalai during 872{{spaced ndash}}900. Aditya also was the patron of Sureswara aand prabhakara who were pupils of kumarila bhatta a favourite student of Adisankaracharya. The author of that work do confirm that they settled in the banks of Kaveri (Sibishu kaveriteere meaning in the country of cholas (Sibi is an ancestor of Cholas)) and were employed by Manukula Adityan (Aditya Chola). == Death and Succession == In an inscription Aditya{{ }}I is distinguished by the epithet in Tamil{{spaced ndash}}(‡Æ§‡Øä‡Æ£‡Øç‡Æü‡Øà‡ÆÆ‡Ææ‡Æ©‡Æ∞‡ØÇ‡Æ∞‡Øç ‡Æ§‡ØÅ‡Æû‡Øç‡Æö‡Æø‡Æ© ‡Æâ‡Æü‡Øà‡ÆØ‡Ææ‡Æ∞‡Øç ''Thondaimaanaruur thunjina udaiyaar''). "The king who died at Tondaimanarrur". Aditya{{ }}I died in 907 CE at Tondaimanarrur. His son [[Parantaka I]] built a Shiva temple over his ashes. Aditya{{ }}I was survived by his queens ''Ilangon Pichchi'' and ''Vayiri Akkan'' alias ''Tribhuvana Madeviyar''. Besides these two queens, Aditya{{ }}I also had a mistress named ''Nangai Sattaperumanar'' as evidenced from an inscription. Aditya{{ }}I had a long and victorious reign during which he laid the foundation of the future greatness of the Chola empire. == References == {{reflist}} * Tamil And Sanskrit Inscriptions Chiefly Collected In 1886 - 87, E. {{More footnotes|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Ariobarzanes of Persis | image = Ariobarzan statue ÿ™ŸÜÿØ€åÿ≥ ÿ¢ÿ±€åŸàÿ®ÿ±ÿ≤ŸÜ - panoramio.jpg | alt = | caption = | native_name = ''*ƒÄriya-b·πõdƒÅna-'' | native_name_lang = peo | pronunciation = | birth_date = 368 BC | birth_place = [[Persepolis]], [[Achaemenid Empire|Persia]] | death_date = 20 January 330 BC | death_place = [[Persian Gates]], near Persepolis | death_cause = | body_discovered = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | burial_place = <!-- may be used instead of resting_place and resting_place_coordinates (displays "Burial place" as label) --> | burial_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | monuments = | residence = | nationality = | citizenship = | occupation = | years_active = | known_for = Commanding the [[Battle of the Persian Gates]] | title = [[Satrap]] of [[Persis]] | predecessor = | successor = | father = Artabazus | relatives = [[Youtab]] (sister) }} '''Ariobarzanes''' ({{lang-grc|·ºàœÅŒπŒøŒ≤Œ±œÅŒ∂Œ¨ŒΩŒ∑œÇ}}, in [[Old Persian]]: ''*ƒÄriya-b·πõdƒÅna-'', meaning "exalting the Aryans") also spelled as '''Ario Barzan''' or '''Aryo Barzan''' ({{lang-fa|ÿ¢ÿ±€åŸàÿ®ÿ±ÿ≤ŸÜ}}); died 330 BC),<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |last= Shahbazi |first=A. Sh. | title=ARIOBARZANES | encyclopedia=Encyclopedia Iranica | accessdate=2008-03-05|url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/ariobarzanes-greek-form-of-old-iranian-proper-name-arya-brzana}}</ref> also known as '''Ariobarzanes the Brave''',{{cn|date=July 2018}} was an [[Achaemenid]] [[prince]], [[satrap]] and a [[Persian people|Persian]] military commander who led a [[last stand]] of the Persian army at the [[Battle of the Persian Gate]] against Macedonian King [[Alexander the Great]] in the winter of 330 BC.
==Life== Though the exact birth-date of Ariobarzanes is unknown, it is speculated that he was born around 368 BC. His sister was the ancient Persian noblewoman and warrior [[Youtab]]. Ariobarzanes was made satrap of [[Persis]] (the southern province of [[Fars Province|Fars]] in present-day [[Iran]]) in 335 BC by [[Darius III Codomannus]]. Historians are surprised that Darius III appointed a satrap for [[Persepolis]] and [[Persis]]; apparently that office did not previously exist. Ariobarzanes commanded part of the Persian Army fighting against the [[Ancient Macedonians|Macedonians]] at the [[Battle of Gaugamela]] in 331 BC.
==Death== Following the Persian defeat at Gaugamela, Darius realized he could not defend his capital [[Persepolis]] and travelled east to rebuild his armies, leaving Ariobarzanes in command. Meanwhile, Alexander the Great split his army and led his 14,000-strong force towards the Persian capital via the [[Persian Gates]]. There Ariobarzanes successfully ambushed Alexander the Great's army, inflicting heavy casualties. The Persian success at the [[Battle of the Persian Gate]] was short lived though; after being held off for 30 days, Alexander the Great outflanked and destroyed the defenders. Some sources indicate that the Persians were betrayed by a captured tribal chief who showed the Macedonians an alternate path that allowed them to outflank Ariobarzanes in a reversal of [[Battle of Thermopylae|Thermopylae]]. Ariobarzanes himself was killed either during the battle or during the retreat to Persepolis. Afterwards, Alexander continued towards Persepolis, seizing the city and its treasury, and eventually looting the city months after its fall.

Chairman of [[Apple Inc.]] | nationality = American | parents = Malvina and Sol Levinson | spouse = Rita May Liff | children = 2 | religion = }} '''Arthur D. Levinson''' (born March 31, 1950) is an American businessman and is the current Chairman of [[Apple Inc.]] (2011 to present) and [[CEO]] of [[Calico (company)|Calico]] (an [[Alphabet Inc.]] venture). He is the former chief executive officer (1995 to 2009) and chairman (1999 to 2014) of [[Genentech]]. In addition to serving on the board of [[Apple Inc.]] (2000‚Äìpresent), Levinson serves on the board of directors of the [[Broad Institute]] (affiliated with [[MIT]] and [[Harvard]]).{{cite web |url=https://www.apple.com/pr/library/2011/11/15en-US-Apple-Names-Arthur-D-Levinson-Chairman-of-the-Board.html |title=Apple Names Arthur D. Levinson Chairman of the Board |publisher=(Press release) Apple Inc. November 15, 2011}} Previously, Levinson had served on the board of directors at F. [[Hoffmann-La Roche]] (2010-2014), NGM Biopharmaceuticals (2009-2014), and [[Amyris (company)|Amyris Biotechnologies]] (2009-2014). He currently serves on the Board of Scientific Consultants of the [[Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center]], the Industrial Advisory Board of the [[California Institute for Quantitative Biosciences]] (QB3), the Advisory Council for the [[Princeton University]] Department of [[Molecular biology|Molecular Biology]] and the Advisory Council for the Lewis-Sigler Institute for Integrative Genomics.{{cite web |url=http://www.broadinstitute.org/history-leadership/board-directors/bios/arthur-levinson |title=Arthur Levinson Chairman of Genentech Inc. |publisher=Broad Institute}} ==Early life and education== Born to a [[American Jews|Jewish]] family,Rosenbaum, Fred [https://books.google.com/books?id=Kt2HaliLi0EC&pg=PA245 Cosmopolitans: A Social and Cultural History of the Jews of the San Francisco Bay Area"] Nov 2009 the son of Malvina and Sol Levinson, he received his bachelor's degree from the [[University of Washington]] in Seattle in 1972 and his [[PhD]] in [[biochemistry]] from [[Princeton University]] in 1977. == Career == Levinson was a postdoctoral researcher with [[Nobel Prize]] winners [[J. Michael Bishop|Michael Bishop]] and [[Harold Varmus]] in the Department of [[Microbiology]] at the [[University of California, San Francisco]], when [[Herb Boyer]] hired him to work at Genentech.{{cite news| url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/stories/2004/12/20/story1.html | first=Daniel S. | last=Levine | title=Executive of the Year: Arthur Levinson drives Genentech |work=San Francisco Business Times |date=December 19, 2004}} Levinson joined [[Genentech]] in 1980 as a [[research scientist]] and became Vice President of Research Technology in 1989; Vice President of Research in 1990; Senior Vice President of Research in 1992; and Senior Vice President of Research and Development in 1993. Levinson became Genentech's Chief Executive Officer in 1995 and [[Chairman]] in 1999.{{cite press release |url=http://www.gene.com/gene/news/press-releases/display.do?method=print&id=4897 |title=Genentech Names Levinson as New Board Chair and Announces Appointment of Two New Directors |publisher=Genentech |date=September 22, 1999}} Levinson received corporate leadership awards from the Irvington Institute{{cite press release |url=http://www.gene.com/gene/news/press-releases/display.do?method=print&id=4895 |title=Genentech Chairman/CEO Arthur Levinson Receives Irvington Institute's Corporate Leadership Award |publisher=Genentech |date=September 29, 1999}} and the [[National Breast Cancer Coalition]] in 1999.{{cite web|url=http://www.gene.com/gene/about/corporate/awards/past-awards.html |title=Past Awards and Recognition |publisher=Genentech |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110828220823/http://www.gene.com/gene/about/corporate/awards/past-awards.html |archivedate=August 28, 2011 }} Levinson was inducted into the Biotech Hall of Fame at the 2003 Biotech Meeting of CEOs. ''BusinessWeek'' named Levinson one of the "Best Managers of the Year" in 2004 and 2005, and ''[[Institutional Investor (magazine)|Institutional Investor]]'' named him "America's Best CEO" in the biotech category four years in a row (2004‚Äì2007). Levinson served on the Board of Directors of [[Google]] from 2004 to 2009.{{cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2009/10/12/genentechs-and-apple-board-member-arthur-levinson-leaves-google-board/ |first=Doug |last=Aamoth |title=Genentech's (And Apple Board Member) Arthur Levinson Leaves Google Board |work=Techcrunch |date=October 12, 2009}}{{cite press release |url=http://www.google.com/intl/en/press/pressrel/ir_20091012.html |title=Arthur Levinson Resigns from Google's Board of Directors |publisher=Google |date=October 12, 2009}} In 2006, Princeton University awarded Levinson the James Madison Medal for a distinguished career in scientific research and in biotechnology. Also in 2006, ''[[Barron's (newspaper)|Barron's]]'' recognized Levinson as one of "The World's Most Respected CEOs", and the [http://www.bestpracticeinstitute.org/ Best Practice Institute] placed Levinson on their "25 Top CEOs" list. In 2008 Levinson was elected as a Fellow to the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] and [[Glassdoor]] rated him as the "nicest" CEO of 2008 with a 93% approval rating.{{cite news| url=http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/12/26/which-ceos-were-naughty-and-nice-in-2008/ | work=The New York Times | title=Glassdoor.com Lists Naughtiest and Nicest C.E.O.'s of 2008 | date=December 26, 2009}} In 2010, Levinson was honored with the [[Biotechnology Heritage Award]] from the [[Biotechnology Industry Organization]] (BIO) and the [[Chemical Heritage Foundation]], and the Director's Award from the [[San Francisco Exploratorium]].{{cite web |url=http://www.gene.com/gene/about/corporate/awards/ |title=Awards and Recognition |publisher=Genentech}}{{cite web|title= Biotechnology Heritage Award|url=https://www.sciencehistory.org/node/285|website=[[Science History Institute]]|accessdate=21 February 2018}} Levinson has authored or co-authored more than 80 scientific articles and has been a named inventor on 11 United States patents. On November 15, 2011, Levinson was named Chairman of the Board for [[Apple Inc.]], replacing [[Steve Jobs]].{{cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/briancaulfield/2011/11/15/genentechs-art-levinson-replaces-steve-jobs-as-chairman-of-apples-board/ |title=Genentech's Art Levinson Replaces Steve Jobs As Chairman Of Apple's Board |publisher=Forbes | first=Brian |last=Caulfield}} As the Chairman, his total compensation for 2012 was $457,222.[https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/320193/000119312513005529/d450591ddef14a.htm Definitive Proxy Statement]. Sec.gov. Retrieved on 2013-11-24. On September 18, 2013, Levinson was named CEO of [[Calico (company)|Calico]], a new company focusing on health and well-being. The company was created and funded by Google.{{cite web|title=Google announces Calico, a new company focused on health and well-being|url=http://googlepress.blogspot.com.es/2013/09/calico-announcement.html}} In 2014 he received the Alumnus Summa Laude Dignatus Award from the University of Washington, the highest honor bestowed upon a Washington graduate.{{cite news |url=http://www.biology.washington.edu/news/art-levinson-72-announced-2014-alumnus-summa-laude-dignatus |title=ALUMNI SUMMA LAUDE DIGNATI |publisher=University of Washington }} On October 3, 2014, Levinson received the National Medal of Technology and Innovation, the nation's highest honor for achievement and leadership in advancing the fields of science and technology.{{cite web|title=President Obama Honors Nation's Top Scientists and Innovators|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2014/10/03/president-obama-honors-nation-s-top-scientists-and-innovators|website=The White House|accessdate=6 September 2016}} In April 2016, Levinson was awarded the 2016 Distinguished Alumnus Award from the University of California, San Francisco for his contributions to the scientific community.{{cite web|title=Art Levinson Honored by UCSF Graduate Division at 2016 Alumni Weekend|url=http://graduate.ucsf.edu/news/art-levinson-honored|website=UCSF Graduation Division|accessdate=6 September 2016}} As of September 2016, he is reported to own approximately 1.2 million Apple shares worth of US$128 million.{{Cite web|url=https://www.insidermole.com/insider/levinson-arthur-d|title=ARTHUR D LEVINSON Insider Trading Overview|website=www.insidermole.com|access-date=2016-09-05}} == Personal life == He married Rita May Liff on December 17, 1978 and they have two children. ==See also== {{Wikipedia books|Apple Inc.}} {{machine learning bar}} [[File:Autoencoder_structure.png|350x350px|Schematic structure of an autoencoder with 3 fully connected hidden layers.|thumb]] An '''autoencoder''' is a type of [[artificial neural network]] used to learn [[Feature learning|efficient data codings]] in an [[unsupervised learning|unsupervised]] manner.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/j.neucom.2008.04.030|title=Modeling word perception using the Elman network|journal=Neurocomputing|volume=71|issue=16‚Äì18|pages=3150|year=2008|last1=Liou|first1=Cheng-Yuan|last2=Huang|first2=Jau-Chi|last3=Yang|first3=Wen-Chie}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/j.neucom.2013.09.055|title=Autoencoder for words|journal=Neurocomputing|volume=139|pages=84|year=2014|last1=Liou|first1=Cheng-Yuan|last2=Cheng|first2=Wei-Chen|last3=Liou|first3=Jiun-Wei|last4=Liou|first4=Daw-Ran}}</ref> The aim of an autoencoder is to learn a representation (encoding) for a set of data, typically for [[dimensionality reduction]]. Recently, the autoencoder concept has become more widely used for learning [[generative model]]s of data.<ref name="VAE">{{cite arxiv|eprint=1312.6114|author1=Diederik P Kingma|title=Auto-Encoding Variational Bayes|last2=Welling|first2=Max|class=stat.ML|year=2013}}</ref><ref name="gan_faces">Generating Faces with Torch, Boesen A., Larsen L. and Sonderby S.K., 2015 {{url|http://torch.ch/blog/2015/11/13/gan.html}}</ref> Some of the most powerful AI in the 2010s have involved sparse autoencoders stacked inside of deep neural networks.<ref name=domingos>{{cite book |first1=Pedro |last1=Domingos |author-link=Pedro Domingos|year=2015|title=[[The Master Algorithm|The Master Algorithm: How the Quest for the Ultimate Learning Machine Will Remake Our World]] |publisher= Basic Books |isbn= 978-046506192-1 |chapter=4 |at= "Deeper into the Brain" subsection}}</ref>
==Purpose== An autoencoder learns to compress data from the input layer into a short code, and then uncompress that code into something that closely matches the original data. This forces the autoencoder to engage in dimensionality reduction, for example by learning how to ignore noise. Some architectures use stacked sparse autoencoder layers for image recognition. The first autoencoder might learn to encode easy features like corners, the second to analyze the first layer's output and then encode less local features like the tip of a nose, the third might encode a whole nose, etc., until the final autoencoder encodes the whole image into a code that matches (for example) the concept of "cat".<ref name=domingos/> An alternative use is as a generative model: for example, if a system is manually fed the codes it has learned for "cat" and "flying", it may attempt to generate an image of a flying cat, even if it has never seen a flying cat before.<ref name="VAE"/><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hutson|first1=Matthew|title=New algorithm can create movies from just a few snippets of text|journal=Science|date=23 February 2018|doi=10.1126/science.aat4126}}</ref>
==Structure== Architecturally, the simplest form of an autoencoder is a [[feedforward neural network|feedforward]], non-[[recurrent neural network|recurrent]] neural network very similar to the many single layer perceptrons which makes a [[multilayer perceptron]] (MLP) ‚Äì having an input layer, an output layer and one or more hidden layers connecting them ‚Äì but with the output layer having the same number of nodes as the input layer, and with the purpose of ''reconstructing'' its own inputs (instead of predicting the target value <math>Y</math> given inputs <math>X</math>). Therefore, autoencoders are [[unsupervised learning]] models.
An autoencoder always consists of two parts, the encoder and the decoder, which can be defined as transitions <math>\phi</math> and <math>\psi,</math> such that:
:<math>\phi:\mathcal{X} \rightarrow \mathcal{F}</math> :<math>\psi:\mathcal{F} \rightarrow \mathcal{X}</math> :<math>\phi,\psi = \underset{\phi,\psi}{\operatorname{arg\,min}}\, \|X-(\psi \circ \phi) X\|^2</math>
In the simplest case, where there is one hidden layer, the encoder stage of an autoencoder takes the input <math>\mathbf{x} \in \mathbb{R}^d = \mathcal{X}</math> and maps it to <math>\mathbf{z} \in \mathbb{R}^p = \mathcal{F}</math>:
:<math>\mathbf{z} = \sigma(\mathbf{Wx}+\mathbf{b})</math>
This image <math>\mathbf{z}</math> is usually referred to as ''code'', ''latent variables'', or ''latent representation''. Here, <math>\sigma</math> is an element-wise [[activation function]] such as a [[sigmoid function]] or a [[rectified linear unit]]. <math>\mathbf{W}</math> is a weight matrix and <math>\mathbf{b}</math> is a bias vector. After that, the decoder stage of the autoencoder maps <math>\mathbf{z}</math> to the ''reconstruction'' <math>\mathbf{x'}</math> of the same shape as <math>\mathbf{x}</math>:
:<math>\mathbf{x'} = \sigma'(\mathbf{W'z}+\mathbf{b'})</math>
where <math>\mathbf{\sigma'}, \mathbf{W'}, \text{ and }\mathbf{b'}</math> for the decoder may differ in general from the corresponding <math>\mathbf{\sigma}, \mathbf{W}, \text{ and } \mathbf{b}</math> for the encoder, depending on the design of the autoencoder.
Autoencoders are also trained to minimise reconstruction errors (such as [[Mean squared error|squared errors]]):
:<math>\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{x'})=\|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x'}\|^2=\|\mathbf{x}-\sigma'(\mathbf{W'}(\sigma(\mathbf{Wx}+\mathbf{b}))+\mathbf{b'})\|^2</math>
where <math>\mathbf{x}</math> is usually averaged over some input training set.
If the [[feature (machine learning)|feature space]] <math>\mathcal{F}</math> has lower dimensionality than the input space <math>\mathcal{X}</math>, then the feature vector <math>\phi(x)</math> can be regarded as a [[Data compression|compressed]] representation of the input <math>x</math>. If the hidden layers are larger than the input layer, an autoencoder can potentially learn the [[identity function]] and become useless. However, experimental results have shown that autoencoders might still [[feature learning|learn useful features]] in these cases.<ref name="bengio">{{Cite journal|last1=Bengio|first1=Y.|year=2009|title=Learning Deep Architectures for AI|url=http://www.iro.umontreal.ca/~lisa/pointeurs/TR1312.pdf|journal=Foundations and Trends in Machine Learning|volume=2|pages=1|doi=10.1561/2200000006|pmc=|pmid=}}</ref>{{rp|19}}
===Variations===
Various techniques exist to prevent autoencoders from learning the identity function and to improve their ability to capture important information and learn richer representations:
====Denoising autoencoder====
Denoising autoencoders take a partially corrupted input whilst training to recover the original undistorted input. This technique has been introduced with a specific approach to ''good'' representation.<ref name="ref9">{{cite journal | last1 = Vincent | first1 = Pascal | last2 = Larochelle | first2 = Hugo | last3 = Lajoie | first3 = Isabelle | last4 = Bengio | first4 = Yoshua | last5 = Manzagol | first5 = Pierre-Antoine | title = Stacked Denoising Autoencoders: Learning Useful Representations in a Deep Network with a Local Denoising Criterion | journal = The Journal of Machine Learning Research | volume = 11 | pages = 3371‚Äì3408 | date = 2010 | url = http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=1953039}}</ref> A ''good'' representation is one that can be obtained [[Robustness (computer science)|robustly]] from a corrupted input and that will be useful for recovering the corresponding clean input.'' This definition contains the following implicit assumptions:
* The higher level representations are relatively stable and robust to the corruption of the input; * It is necessary to extract features that are useful for representation of the input distribution.
To train an autoencoder to denoise data, it is necessary to perform preliminary stochastic mapping <math>\mathbf{x}\rightarrow\mathbf{\tilde{x}}</math> in order to corrupt the data and use <math>\mathbf{\tilde{x}}</math> as input for a normal autoencoder, with the only exception being that the [[Loss function|loss]] should still be computed for the initial input <math>\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{\tilde{x}'})</math> instead of <math>\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{\tilde{x}},\mathbf{\tilde{x}'})</math>.
====Sparse autoencoder====
Autoencoders were originally invented in the 1980s; however, the initial versions were difficult to train, as the encodings have to compete to set the same small set of bits. This was solved by "sparse autoencoding". In a sparse autoencoder, there are actually more (rather than fewer) hidden units than inputs, but only a small number of the hidden units are allowed to be active at the same time.<ref name=domingos/>
Sparsity may be achieved by additional terms in the [[loss function]] during training (by [[Kullback‚ÄìLeibler divergence|comparing the probability distribution]] of the hidden unit activations with some low desired value),<ref>{{citation|title=sparse autoencoders|url=https://web.stanford.edu/class/cs294a/sparseAutoencoder.pdf}}</ref> or by manually zeroing all but the few strongest hidden unit activations (referred to as a ''k-sparse autoencoder'').<ref>{{cite arxiv|title=k-sparse autoencoder|eprint=1312.5663|last1=Makhzani|first1=Alireza|last2=Frey|first2=Brendan|class=cs.LG|year=2013}}</ref>
====Variational autoencoder (VAE)====
Variational autoencoder models inherit autoencoder architecture, but make strong assumptions concerning the distribution of latent variables. They use [[Variational Bayesian methods|variational approach]] for latent representation learning, which results in an additional loss component and specific training algorithm called ''Stochastic Gradient Variational Bayes (SGVB)''.<ref name="VAE" /> It assumes that the data is generated by a directed [[graphical model]] <math>p(\mathbf{x}|\mathbf{z})</math> and that the encoder is learning an approximation <math>q_{\phi}(\mathbf{z}|\mathbf{x})</math> to the [[Posterior probability|posterior distribution]] <math>p_{\theta}(\mathbf{z}|\mathbf{x})</math> where <math>\mathbf{\phi}</math> and <math>\mathbf{\theta}</math> denote the parameters of the encoder (recognition model) and decoder (generative model) respectively. The objective of the variational autoencoder in this case has the following form: :<math>\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{\phi},\mathbf{\theta},\mathbf{x})=D_{\mathrm{KL}}(q_{\phi}(\mathbf{z}|\mathbf{x})\Vert p_{\theta}(\mathbf{z}))-\mathbb{E}_{q_{\phi}(\mathbf{z}|\mathbf{x})}\big(\log p_{\theta}(\mathbf{x}|\mathbf{z})\big)</math> Here, <math>D_{\mathrm{KL}}</math> stands for the [[Kullback‚ÄìLeibler divergence]]. The prior over the latent variables is usually set to be the centred isotropic multivariate Gaussian <math>p_{\theta}(\mathbf{z})=\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{0,I})</math>; however, alternative configurations have also been recently considered, e.g.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/j.neucom.2017.02.028|title=Asymmetric deep generative models|journal=Neurocomputing|volume=241|pages=90|year=2017|last1=Partaourides|first1=Harris|last2=Chatzis|first2=Sotirios P}}</ref>
==== Contractive autoencoder (CAE) ==== Contractive autoencoder adds an explicit regularizer in their objective function that forces the model to learn a function that is robust to slight variations of input values. This regularizer corresponds to the [[Frobenius norm]] of the [[Jacobian matrix and determinant|Jacobian matrix]] of the encoder activations with respect to the input. The final objective function has the following form: :<math>\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{x'}) + \lambda \sum_i || \nabla_x h_i ||^2</math>
===Relationship with principal component analysis (PCA)=== If linear activations are used, or only a single sigmoid hidden layer, then the optimal solution to an autoencoder is strongly related to [[principal component analysis]] (PCA).<ref>{{Cite journal| last1 = Bourlard | first1 = H. | last2 = Kamp | first2 = Y. | doi = 10.1007/BF00332918 | title = Auto-association by multilayer perceptrons and singular value decomposition | journal = Biological Cybernetics | volume = 59 | issue = 4‚Äì5 | pages = 291‚Äì294 | year = 1988 | pmid = 3196773| pmc = }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|doi=10.1145/2649387.2649442|chapter=Deep autoencoder neural networks for gene ontology annotation predictions|title=Proceedings of the 5th ACM Conference on Bioinformatics, Computational Biology, and Health Informatics - BCB '14|pages=533|year=2014|last1=Chicco|first1=Davide|last2=Sadowski|first2=Peter|last3=Baldi|first3=Pierre|isbn=9781450328944}}</ref> The weights of an autoencoder with a single hidden layer of size <math>p</math> (where <math>p</math> is less than the size of the input) span the same vector subspace as the one spanned by the first <math>p</math> principal components, and the output of the autoencoder is an orthogonal projection onto this subspace. The autoencoder weights are not equal to the principal components, and are generally not orthogonal, yet the principal components may be recovered from them using the [[Gram-Schmidt process]].<ref>{{cite arxiv|last1=Plaut|first1=E|title=From Principal Subspaces to Principal Components with Linear Autoencoders|eprint=1804.10253|date=2018|class=stat.ML}}</ref>
==Training== The training algorithm for an autoencoder can be summarized as :For each input {{mvar|x}}, ::Do a feed-forward pass to compute activations at all hidden layers, then at the output layer to obtain an output <math>\mathbf{x'}</math> ::Measure the deviation of <math>\mathbf{x'}</math> from the input <math>\mathbf{x}</math> (typically using [[Mean squared error|squared error]]), ::[[Backpropagation|Backpropagate]] the error through the net and perform weight updates.
An autoencoder is often trained using one of the many variants of [[backpropagation]] (such as [[conjugate gradient method]], [[steepest descent]], etc.). Though these are often reasonably effective, there are fundamental problems with the use of backpropagation to train networks with many hidden layers. Once errors are backpropagated to the first few layers, they become minuscule and insignificant. This means that the network will almost always learn to reconstruct the average of all the training data.{{Citation needed|date=December 2013}} Though more advanced backpropagation methods (such as the conjugate gradient method) can solve this problem to a certain extent, they still result in a very slow learning process and poor solutions. This problem can be remedied by using initial weights that approximate the final solution. The process of finding these initial weights is often referred to as ''pretraining''.
Stephen Luttrell, while based at [[RSRE]], developed a technique for unsupervised training of hierarchical self-organizing neural nets with "many hidden layers",<ref>{{cite book |last=Luttrell |first=S. P. |chapter-url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/abstract/document/51919 |chapter=Hierarchical self-organising networks |title=1989 First IEE International Conference on Artificial Neural Networks |pages=2‚Äì6 |location=London |publisher=Institution of Engineering and Technology|date=October 1989}}</ref> which are equivalent to deep autoencoders. [[Geoffrey Hinton]] developed an alternative pretraining technique for training many-layered deep autoencoders. This method involves treating each neighbouring set of two layers as a [[restricted Boltzmann machine]] so that the pretraining approximates a good solution, then using a backpropagation technique to fine-tune the results.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hinton|first1=G. E.|last2=Salakhutdinov|first2=R.R.|title=Reducing the Dimensionality of Data with Neural Networks|journal=Science|date=28 July 2006|volume=313|issue=5786|pages=504‚Äì507|doi=10.1126/science.1127647|bibcode=2006Sci...313..504H}}</ref> This model takes the name of [[deep belief network]].

<!--[[File:Bongi Makeba.jpg|thumb|MAKEBA on the cover of her album ''Blow On Wind'']]--> {{Infobox person | name = Bongi Makeba | image = Bongi Makeba.jpg | image_size = 260px | alt = | caption = Makeba on the cover of her album ''Blow On Wind'' | birth_name = Angela Sibongile Makeba | birth_date = {{Birth date|1950|12|20|df=y}} | birth_place = [[South Africa]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1985|03|17|1950|12|20|df=y}} | death_place = | burial_place = [[Conakry, Guinea]] | nationality = South African | other_names = | occupation = Singer, songwriter | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }} '''Bongi Makeba''' (20 December 1950 – 17 March 1985) was a [[South Africa]]n singer/songwriter. She was the only child of singer [[Miriam Makeba]] with her first husband, James Kubay.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.joburg.org.za/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=3174&Itemid=245# |title=Rudo Mungoshi, "Hamba kahle, Mama Africa", Joburg official website: www.joburg.org.za, 14 November 2008. |access-date=2012-06-20 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130729143142/http://www.joburg.org.za/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=3174&Itemid=245# |archive-date=2013-07-29 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Biography== Angela Sibongile Makeba was born in South Africa in 1950, when her mother was 18 years old. The name Bongi by which she became known is a shortened version of her middle name Sibongile, which means "We are grateful".<ref>[http://www.miriammakeba.org/estate/bongi-makeba "Bongi Makeba"], Miriam Makeba Foundation.</ref> In 1959 her mother's career took her to New York, where she remained in exile after being barred from returning to South Africa, and in 1960 was joined by Bongi, who stayed with friends while her mother toured the world.<ref>[http://www.lipstickalley.com/showthread.php/451583-The-Strength-of-a-Black-Woman-Miriam-Makeba-(Mama-Africa)-and-Apartheid-(long-read) "The Strength of a Black Woman: Miriam Makeba (Mama Africa) and Apartheid"], Lipstick Alley, 21 November 2012.</ref><ref name=Weinberg>Samantha Weinberg, [https://swco-ir.tdl.org/swco-ir/bitstream/handle/10605/4379/Southwest_Digest__1995-10-12.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=y Called Home: Children South African Exiles Return to Their Native Land"], ''Southwest Digest'', 12‚Äì18 October 1995.</ref>
In 1967 she and Judy White, daughter of [[Josh White]], signed to [[Buddha Records]] as "Bongi and Judy", their first release being "Runnin' Out" and "Let's Get Together".<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=9ycEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA22&lpg=PA22&dq=%22Bongi++makeba%22&source=bl&ots=vCJQgaKy1N&sig=GMsWepV4Oez9BC1btwwuizYy24A&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjA3e-txvnPAhXHCMAKHSXuAlU4MhDoAQgkMAE#v=onepage&q=%22Bongi%20%20makeba%22&f=false "Signings"], ''[[Billboard magazine|Billboard]]'', October 7, 1967, p. 22.</ref> At the age of 17, Makeba met her American husband Harold Nelson Lee, with whom in the early to mid-1970s she made two 7" records as "Bongi and Nelson", featuring two soul tracks arranged by George Butcher: "That's the Kind of Love" backed by "I Was So Glad" (France: Syliphone SYL 533), and "Everything, For My Love" with "Do You Remember, Malcolm?" (France: Syliphone SYL 532).<ref name="discogs"/> She recorded only one solo album, ''Bongi Makeba, Blow On Wind''<ref name="discogs">[http://www.discogs.com/artist/Bongi+Makeba Bongi Makeba discography]</ref><ref>[http://www.discogs.com/Murtala-Bongi-Makeba-Blow-On-Wind/release/2024656 Murtala Bongi Makeba ‚Äì Blow On Wind]</ref> (pl√§ne-records), in 1980. Some of her songs could be heard years later in her mother's repertoire. Two of them, "Malcolm X" (1965, 1972) and "Lumumba" (1970) extol assassinated black leaders.
Makeba had three children:<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/7719318.stm "Obituary: Miriam 'Mama Africa' Makeba"], BBC News, 11 November 2008.</ref> Nelson Lumumba Lee (born 1968), Zenzi Monique Lee (born 1971),<ref name=Weinberg /><ref>Patrick Phosa, [http://www.artlink.co.za/news_article.htm?contentID=10132 "Zenzi Lee"], ''The Star Tonight'', 5 January 1999.</ref> and a son, Themba, who died as a young child.<ref>{{cite book |last= Makeba|first= Miriam|date= 1992 |title= Miriam Makeba - Etel√§-Afrikan √§√§ni|trans-title=|url= |location= |publisher= Kirjayhtym√§|isbn= 951-26-3738-3|language=fi}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Nkrumah |first=Gamal |title=Mama Africa |work=Profile |date=1‚Äì7 November 2001 |issue=558 |publisher=''[[Al-Ahram Weekly]]'' |location=Cairo, Egypt |url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2001/558/profile.htm |accessdate=26 March 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Jon |last=Pareles|authorlink=Jon Pareles |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/03/08/books/books-of-the-times-south-african-singer-s-life-trials-and-triumphs.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm|title=Books of the Times; South African Singer's Life: Trials and Triumphs |work=Books |publisher=''The New York Times'' |date=8 March 1988 |accessdate=26 March 2012}}</ref>
She died aged 34 in 1985 of complications following childbirth and was buried in [[Conakry]], [[Guinea]], where her mother had moved after her 1968 marriage to [[Stokely Carmichael]].

{{short description| Scottish confectioner and amateur diving bell designer }} {{For|the American writer and financier|Charles F. Spalding}} {{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}}
[[File:Charles Spalding Diving Bell, The Saturday Magazine, Vol. 14, 1839.png|right|thumb|230ps|Spalding's Diving Bell, ''The Saturday Magazine'', Vol. 14, 1839]] '''Charles Spalding''' (29 October 1738 ‚Äì 2 June 1783) was an [[Edinburgh]] confectioner and amateur [[engineer]] who made improvements to the [[diving bell]]. He died while diving to the [[Shipwreck|wreck]] of the ''Belgioso'' in [[Dublin Bay]] using a diving bell of his own design.
==Early life== Charles Spalding was born in [[Canongate]] in [[Scotland]] on 29 October 1738, the son of Charles Spalding and Ann Findlay.<ref name="Charles Spalding Birth Record">{{cite journal|last=Spalding|first=Charles|title=Old Parish Registers, Births & Baptisms|date=29 October 1738|volume=685/03/0080/270}}</ref> His father was a [[bookseller]] in Canongate.<ref name="The Edinburgh Marriage Register" /><ref name="Charles Spalding, Bookseller, Will 1786">{{cite book|title=Will of Charles Spalding, Bookseller|date=25 January 1786|location=Edinburgh, Scotland Commissary Court|edition=Reference CC8/8/127}}</ref> As the son of a [[merchant]], the younger Spalding eventually became a shop-lad.<ref name="The Technical Educator" />
Possessing a natural inclination towards [[mechanics]], Spalding spent much of his free time as a youth exploring this interest.<ref name="The Technical Educator" /> Spalding eventually became the proprietor of a [[sugar refinery|sugar refining]] and [[Confectionery store|confectionery shop]] across from the [[Edinburgh City Chambers|Royal Exchange]] on the [[Royal Mile]] in Edinburgh.<ref name="The Technical Educator">{{cite book|title=The Technical Educator, An Encyclop√¶dia|year=1871|publisher=Cassell, Petter, and Galpin|location=London, Paris, New York|pages=29‚Äì31|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Ky4CAAAAQAAJ&pg=RA1-PA30&dq=%22ebenezer+watson%22+edinburgh#v=onepage&q=%22ebenezer%20watson%22%20edinburgh&f=false|edition=Volume III}}</ref><ref name="Thomas Tegg">{{cite book|last=Tegg|first=Thomas|title=London Encyclopaedia; Or, Universal Dictionary of Science, Art, Literature & Practical Mechanics|year=1829|location=London, England|pages=716|edition=Volume XX}}</ref><ref name="The London Encyclopaedia">{{cite book|last=Curtis|first=Thomas|title=The London Encyclopaedia|year=1829|location=London, England|url=https://books.google.com/?id=dHVMAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA716&dq=%22royal+exchange%22+edinburgh+spalding#v=onepage&q=%22royal%20exchange%22%20edinburgh%20spalding&f=false|edition=Volume XX}}</ref>
==Improvements to Halley's diving bell== Spalding's introduction to diving was more the result of necessity than choice. Heavily invested in the [[brig]] ''Peggy'', Spalding suffered a severe financial blow when she sank ''en route'' to Scotland at the [[Farne Islands]]<ref name="Dr. John Bevan Paper">{{cite journal|last=Bevan|first=Dr. John|title=Paper: Charles Spalding's Diving Bells|journal=Presented to a meeting of the Historical Diving Society at Norwegian Underwater Institute, Bergen|date=5 November 2005}}</ref> on 4 December 1774.<ref name="Society of Arts" /> Elected by his Edinburgh trade [[guild]] to recover as many goods as possible, Spalding came up with the idea of diving to the wreck.<ref name="Society of Arts" />
The prevailing diving bell design in 1775 was that of Dr. [[Edmond Halley]] (1656‚Äì1742), who had computed the orbit of the [[Halley's Comet|comet]] named for him.<ref name="Society of Arts" /> Using his background in mechanics, Spalding read every book he could find on the design of Halley's diving bell, eventually proceeding to trial dives in the port of [[Leith]], [[Dunbar]] Bay and at [[Dundee]].<ref name="Society of Arts" /> Based on these trials, Spalding determined that Halley's design had weaknesses that added unnecessary risk to the divers.<ref name="The Saturday Magazine" /> To correct the deficiencies, Spalding added a system of balance-weights to ease the raising and lowering of the bell, along with a series of ropes for signalling the surface crew.<ref name="Dublin A Cultural History" /> The redesigned diving bell weighed {{convert|200|lb|kg|abbr=on}} and could accommodate two divers.<ref name="Dublin A Cultural History" /> Spalding also added ropes inside in the bell as seats and thick glass windows to admit light.<ref name="The Technical Educator" />
Spalding never recovered any of his own cargo from the wreck of the ''Peggy''.<ref name="Society of Arts" /> However, in 1776 Spalding was recognised by The Society for the Encouragement of Arts, Manufactures and Commerce, London, with a nominal monetary award for his modified diving bell design.<ref name="Society of Arts">{{cite book|title=Transactions of the Society Instituted at London for the Encouragement of Arts, Manufactures, and Commerce|year=1806|publisher=Society of Arts|location=Great Britain|pages=220‚Äì232|url=https://books.google.com/?id=zxtbAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA232&dq=%22charles+spalding%22+edinburgh#v=onepage&q=%22charles%20spalding%22%20edinburgh&f=false|edition=The Third Edition, Volume 1}}</ref><ref name="The Saturday Magazine">{{cite book|last=Parker|first=John William|title=The Saturday Magazine|year=1839|publisher=Society for Promoting Christian Knowledge (Great Britain)|location=London|pages=199‚Äì200|edition=Volume 14}}</ref>
With this success, Spalding founded ''Spalding & Co.'' of Edinburgh for his diving operations.<ref name="Dublin A Cultural History">{{cite book|last=Kilfeather|first=Siobh√°n|title=Dublin : a cultural history|year=2005|publisher=Oxford Univ. Press|location=New York [u.a.]|isbn=9780195182019|pages=63‚Äì65|url=https://books.google.com/?id=8QWZRVAPa6sC&pg=PA63&dq=%22Charles+spalding%22+%22royal+george%22#v=onepage&q=%22Charles%20spalding%22%20%22royal%20george%22&f=false|edition=2nd ed., 113 th impression.|accessdate=23 January 2013}}</ref> Spalding was assisted in his diving efforts by his brother Thomas (b. 1740), George Small, who was married to Spalding's sister Ann, and his nephew, Ebenezer Watson.<ref name="Dr. John Bevan Paper" />
== HMS ''Royal George''== [[File:Sinking of Royal George 1782.jpg|left|thumb|170px|Sinking of {{HMS|Royal George|1756|6}} at Spithead, 1782]] On 29 August 1782, the warship {{HMS|Royal George|1756|6}} [[capsizing|capsized]] while under repairs and sank off [[Spithead]], near the port of [[Portsmouth]].<ref name="Treasure Hunt" /> HMS ''Royal George'' was the pride of [[King George III]]'s navy and one of the last British [[Man-of-war]] to be primarily outfitted with more expensive [[brass]] guns rather than lead.<ref name="Treasure Hunt">{{cite book|last=Earle|first=Peter|title=Treasure Hunt: Shipwreck, Diving, and the Quest for Treasure in an Age of Heroes|year=2007|publisher=Macmillan|location=New York City|pages=256|url=https://books.google.com/?id=ZchD115mtg4C&pg=PA256&dq=%22thomas+spalding%22+%22royal+george%22#v=onepage&q=%22thomas%20spalding%22%20%22royal%20george%22&f=false|accessdate=20 January 2013|isbn=9780312380397}}</ref> The [[weapons|ordnance]] alone was valued at ¬£17,000.<ref name="Treasure Hunt" />
One of the first people on the scene with a diving background was Thomas Spalding, Charles' brother.<ref name="Dr. John Bevan Paper" /> As a surgeon on an [[East Indiaman]], Thomas happened to be in Portsmouth shortly after the sinking occurred.<ref name="Dr. John Bevan Paper" /> He immediately proposed to the [[Admiralty]] that he and his brother should be allowed to recover as much valuable stores and ordnance from the wreck as possible using his brother's diving bell design.<ref name="Dr. John Bevan Paper" /> The terms of the salvage arrangement were that Spalding would receive one-third of everything he recovered.<ref name="The Technical Educator" />
Thomas Spalding initially completed several [[reconnaissance]] dives before Charles arrived at the site on 2 October 1782 to begin diving.<ref name="Dr. John Bevan Paper" /> Charles worked on the wreck through most of October 1782 until the beginning of November.<ref name="Treasure Hunt" /> Spalding's dives were complicated by weather, the inexperience of the crew in working with the bell, and the amount of [[debris]] at the dive site.<ref name="Treasure Hunt" /> Overall, Spalding raised 15 guns from the wreck, 9 brass and 6 lead.<ref name="Dr. John Bevan Paper" /> Spalding's proceeds from his salvage of HMS ''Royal George'' were approximately ¬£400.<ref name="The Technical Educator" /> Spalding later learned that the Admiralty had awarded William Tracey of [[Portsea, Portsmouth]] the [[salvage rights]] to the wreck for the following spring.<ref name="Dr. John Bevan Paper" />
==The ''Belgioso''== [[File:Charles Spalding Diving Bell, The Pictorial Gallery of Arts, London Printing and Publishing, 1860.jpg|thumb|right|Charles Spalding Diving Bell, c. 1860]] Undeterred, Spalding turned his attention to the wreck of the ''Belgioso''.
In March 1783, the ''Belgioso'' or ''Count de Belgioso'' Imperial East Indiaman was sailing from [[Liverpool]] ''en route'' to China when it sank in a storm at [[Kish Bank]] near [[Dublin Bay]] in the [[Irish Sea]].<ref name="Irish Wrecks Database">{{cite web|title=Irish Wrecks Database|url=http://www.irishwrecks.com/About.aspx|accessdate=19 January 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131001094701/http://irishwrecks.com/About.aspx|archivedate=1 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The cargo of the ''Belgioso'' was valued at ¬£150,000, with ¬£30,000 in silver and lead.<ref name="The Technical Educator" /> The salvage terms agreed to by the owners were that Spalding would keep one-fourth of all silver and lead recovered and one-half of all other cargo.<ref name="The Technical Educator" /> Additionally, if Spalding failed to recover anything, his entire expense for the operation would be defrayed.<ref name="The Technical Educator" />
Spalding and his nephew, Ebenezer Watson, arrived in Dublin in May 1783 to begin their dive preparations.<ref name="The Technical Educator" /> On 1 June 1783 they began their dives, making three dives to {{convert|7|fathom|ft|lk=in}} to the wreck.<ref name="Dr. John Bevan Paper" /> Typical for the start of a new project, the three dives were plagued with issues.<ref name="Dr. John Bevan Paper" />
On the morning of 2 June 1783, Spalding and Watson resumed diving.<ref name="Dr. John Bevan Paper" /> Approximately one hour and fifteen minutes had elapsed when the dive crew became concerned.<ref name="Dr. John Bevan Paper" /> Two to three barrels of air had been sent down with no progress signal from the bell.<ref name="Dr. John Bevan Paper" /> Since the dive time was longer than usual, the dive crew proceeded to lift the bell.<ref name="Dr. John Bevan Paper" /> When the bell broke the surface they found both men dead, "Mr. Spalding reclining on his breast over one of the ropes that was stretched across for the purpose of sitting upon, and Mr. Watson sitting erect in the upper part of the bell".<ref name="The Technical Educator" /><ref name="Dr. John Bevan Paper" /><ref name="The Scots Magazine" />
On Sunday morning, 8 June 1783, Charles Spalding and Ebenezer Watson were laid to rest.<ref name="The Scots Magazine" /> The Irish press had chronicled Spalding's activity at the ''Belgioso'' wreck site, and Spalding had become somewhat of a local celebrity with the Irish citizens.<ref name="The Technical Educator" /> Many influential Dublin citizens attended the funeral.<ref name="The Technical Educator" /> In a tribute to Spalding's memory, the ships in Dublin Bay kept their flags lowered until the interment was completed.<ref name="Dr. John Bevan Paper" /><ref name="The Hiberian Magazine">{{cite book|last=Potts|first=James|title=The Hibernian Magazine, Or, Compendium of Entertaining Knowledge|year=1783|publisher=Thomas Walker|location=Dublin, Ireland|pages=333‚Äì335|url=https://books.google.com/?id=w7IRAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA334&dq=spalding+confectioner#v=onepage&q=spalding%20confectioner&f=false|accessdate=21 January 2013}}</ref> The pair were buried in a single grave in [[St. Mark's Church, Dublin|St. Mark's Churchyard]] in Dublin.<ref name="The Scots Magazine">{{cite book|last=Boswell|first=James|title=The Scots Magazine|date=January 1783|publisher=Sands, Brymer, Murray and Cochran|location=Edinburgh, Scotland|pages=324‚Äì325|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Tt8RAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA324&dq=%22charles+spalding%22+%22ebenezer+watson%22|edition=Volume 45|accessdate=19 January 2013}}</ref> The exact location of their grave within the churchyard is unknown.<ref name="The National Maritime Museum of Ireland">{{cite web|title=The National Maritime Museum of Ireland|url=http://www.mariner.ie/history/articles/engineering/historical-diving|accessdate=19 January 2013|author=Dr. Edward J. Bourke, Shipwreck Historian|author2=This article was first published in The International Journal of Diving History Volume 3 Number 1 July 2010|quote=Historical Diving in Ireland|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130102034742/http://www.mariner.ie/history/articles/engineering/historical-diving|archivedate=2 January 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
An [[inquest]] into Spalding's and Watson's deaths was eventually held. The causes reviewed during the hearings varied from the negligence of the dive ship's captain, equipment failure, including tangled signal ropes or the failure of the final cask of air reaching the divers, diver error, putrified air from the rotting cargo of the ''Belgioso'', even [[sabotage]] and alcohol.<ref name="Dr. John Bevan Paper" /><ref name="Irish Wrecks Database" /> Dive experts today think the most plausible explanation is "a highly noxious ''effluvia'' entering the bell which could have come from the [[decomposition|putrifying]] bodies or even the rotting cargo of [[ginseng]] plants in the [[Hold (ship)|cargo hold]]."<ref name="Dr. John Bevan Paper" /> This theory is consistent with the observation that they made no apparent attempt to make an emergency ascent.<ref name="Dr. John Bevan Paper" /> The exact cause of death of Spalding and Watson is unknown.<ref name="Dr. John Bevan Paper" />
==Personal life== On 14 August 1768, Spalding married Susan Small, the daughter of [[James Small (Scottish factor)|James Small]], [[Factor (Scotland)|factor]] of [[Asset forfeiture|forfeited]] Struan estates in [[Perthshire]], Scotland.<ref name="The Edinburgh Marriage Register">{{cite book|last=Grant, W.S.|first=Francis J.|title=The Edinburgh Marriage Register, 1751 ‚Äì 1800|year=1922|publisher=J. Skinner & Company, Ltd.|location=Edinburgh, Scotland|pages=733}}</ref> Susan and her father were members of the Smalls of [[Dirnanean House|Dirnanean]], Perthshire, Scotland.
At Spalding's death, he left his wife and seven children<ref name="The Terrific Register">{{cite book|title=The Terrific Register: Or, Record of Crimes, Judgments, Providences, and Calamities|year=1825|publisher=Sherwood, Jones, and Company|location=London, England|pages=718‚Äì720|url=https://books.google.com/?id=1OwTAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA718&dq=spalding+confectioner#v=onepage&q=spalding%20confectioner&f=false|accessdate=21 January 2013}}</ref> under the age of fourteen; the youngest being just six months old. A public subscription fund was opened in London for the relief of the family.<ref name="The Scots Magazine" /> Spalding's widow continued to operate the confectionery after his death,<ref name="Edinburgh Advertiser, 1790">{{cite news|last=Edinburgh University Subscriptions|title=The Edinburgh Advertiser|newspaper=Edinburgh, Scotland|date=17 September 1790}}</ref> eventually selling the business and moving to [[Musselburgh]],<ref name="The Edinburgh Advertiser 1818">{{cite news|last=Desirable House in Musselburgh for Sale|title=The Edniburgh Advertiser|newspaper=Edinburgh, Scotland|date=27 November 1818}}</ref> where she died on 31 October 1818.<ref name="The Scotsman 1818">{{cite news|last=Deaths|title=The Scotsman Newspaper|newspaper=Edinburgh, Scotland|date=14 November 1818}}</ref>
[[Charles Falconer, Baron Falconer of Thoroton]] is a descendant of Charles Spalding, as is [[Sheila Legge]], the "Surrealist Phantom" from the 1936 [[London International Surrealist Exhibition]].
